sources.full: Unearthed Arcana 2022: The Cleric and Revised Species

entries: Clerics draw power from the realms of the gods and harness it to work miracles. Blessed by a deity, a pantheon, or another immortal entity, a Cleric can reach out to the divine magic of the Outer Planes—where gods dwell—and channel that energy to bolster people and to battle foes.

Because their power is a divine gift, Clerics typically associate themselves with temples or shrines dedicated to whatever deity or other immortal force unlocked their magical ability. Harnessing divine magic doesn't rely on study or training, yet a Cleric might learn formulaic prayers and ancient rites that help them focus their minds and spirits on drawing power from the Outer Planes. Even a Cleric who declines to worship their divine benefactor might perform their benefactor's rites if doing so helps the Cleric feel connected to the immortal realms.

Not every acolyte or officiant at a temple or shrine is a Cleric. Some priests are called to a simple life of temple service, carrying out their devotion through prayer and rituals, not through magic. Some of the most influential high priests are incapable of harnessing divine magic, and a few of them feel threatened when a Cleric appears. Many can pray, and some mortals claim to speak for the gods. But few can marshal the power of those gods the way a Cleric can.

classFeature.name: Channel Divinity
entries: You gain the ability to channel divine energy directly from the Outer Planes, using that energy to fuel magical effects. You start with two such effects: Divine Spark and Turn Undead, each of which is described below. Each time you use your Channel Divinity, you choose which effect to create, and you gain additional effect options at higher levels in this Class.
You can use your Channel Divinity a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
Some Channel Divinity effects require Saving Throws. When you use such an effect from this Class, the DC equals the Spell Save DC from this Class's Spellcasting feature.

entries.name: Divine Spark
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, you point your Holy Symbol at another creature you can see within 30 feet of yourself and focus divine energy at them. Roll a number of d8s equal to your Proficiency Bonus and add the rolls together. You either restore Hit Points to the creature equal to that total or force the creature to make a Constitution Saving Throw. On a failed save, the creature takes Radiant Damage equal to the total, and on a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage (rounded down).

entries.name: Turn Undead
entries: As a {@action Magic|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, you present your Holy Symbol and speak a prayer censuring Undead creatures. Each Undead within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom Saving Throw. If the creature fails its Saving Throw, it is Dazed for 1 minute or until it takes any damage or you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or die. While Dazed in this way, the only Action the creature can take is the {@action Dash|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, and if it Moves, it must end that {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} farther from you than where it started.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have learned to cast Spells through prayer, meditation, and devotion. See the Player's Handbook for the rules on spellcasting. The information below details how you use those rules as a Cleric.

entries.name: Prepared Spells
entries: You have the following Spells prepared: {@spell Cure Wounds}, {@spell Sacred Flame}, {@spell Shield} of Faith, {@spell Spare the Dying}, and {@spell Thaumaturgy}. Alternatively, you can prepare three 0-level Spells (also known as cantrips) and two 1st-level Spells of your choice. Any Spell you prepare for this Class must be a Divine Spell.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, you can pray or meditate and replace any Spell you have prepared for this Class with another Divine Spell of the same level.

At higher levels in this Class, you can prepare more Spells, as shown on the Cleric table. The numbers there determine the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level. For example, as a 4th-level Cleric, you can prepare four different 0-level Spells, four different 1st-level Spells, and three different 2nd-level Spells.
Consult the "Prepared Cleric Spells" section for recommendations on which spells to prepare at higher levels.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Cleric table shows how many Spell Slots you have at each level to cast your Cleric Spells of 1st level and higher; the number of different Spells you can prepare of each level equals the number of Spell Slots you have at that level. For example, as a 5th-level Cleric, you have four 1st-level Spell Slots, three 2nd-level Spell Slots, and two 3rd-level Spell Slots.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your Spellcasting Ability for your Cleric Spells.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a Holy Symbol as a Spellcasting Focus for the Spells you prepare for this Class.

classFeature.name: Holy Order
entries: You have dedicated yourself to one of the following sacred roles, either on your own or as part of a religious order. Choose one of the following options:

items.name: Protector
entries: Trained for battle, you gain Martial Weapon Proficiency and Heavy {@variantrule Armor Training|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

items.name: Scholar
entries: Studying and teaching about lore of the gods and the multiverse, you gain Proficiency in two of the following Skills of your choice: {@skill Arcana}, {@skill History}, {@skill Nature}, {@skill Persuasion}, and {@skill Religion}. Whenever you make an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} using either Skill, you gain a bonus to the check equal to your Wisdom Modifier.

items.name: Thaumaturge
entries: Delving deeper into your divine magical abilities, you can prepare one extra 0level Spell from the Divine Spell list. See your Spellcasting feature for more information on preparing Spells. In addition, you regain one expended use of your Channel Divinity whenever you finish a Short Rest.

classFeature.name: Cleric Subclass
entries: You gain the Life Domain Subclass or another Cleric Subclass of your choice. The Life Domain is detailed after the Cleric's Class description, and other Subclasses will appear in future Unearthed {@skill Arcana} articles.

A Subclass is a specialization that grants you special abilities at certain Cleric levels. For the rest of your career, you gain each of your Subclass's features that are of your Cleric level and lower. This Class's description tells you the levels when your Subclass provides features.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Smite Undead
entries: You can cause your Turn Undead feature to smite the undying; whenever you use Turn Undead, you can roll a number of d8s equal to your Proficiency Bonus and add the rolls together. Each Undead that fails its Saving Throw against that use of Turn Undead takes Radiant Damage equal to the roll's total.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: Divine power infuses you in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your 0-level Spells or your attacks with Weapons, you can also deal {@damage 1d8} Radiant Damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Holy Order
entries: Your sacred duties have expanded, allowing you to choose a second option from the Holy Order feature.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Divine Intervention
entries: You can call on your deity or pantheon to intervene on your behalf when your need is great.

As an Action, describe the assistance you seek, and roll percentile dice. If you roll a number equal to or lower than your Cleric level, the divine power intervenes. The DM chooses the nature of the intervention; the effect of any Divine Spell is appropriate.
If the intervention occurs, you can't use this feature again for {@dice 2d6} days. Otherwise, you can use it again after you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Subclass Feature
entries: You gain a feature from your Cleric Subclass.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Great Divine Intervention
entries: When you use your Divine Intervention feature, it succeeds automatically—no roll required—and you can use it again after {@dice 2d4} days.

classFeature.name: Feat
entries: You gain the Ability Score Improvement Feat or another Feat of your choice for which you qualify.

classFeature.name: Epic Boon
entries: You gain the {@feat Epic Boon of Fate|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or another Epic Boon Feat of your choice.

subclassFeature.name: Life Domain
entries: The Life Domain focuses on the vibrant positive energy—one of the fundamental forces of the universe—that sustains all life. The Clerics who tap into this domain are masters of healing, using that force of life to cure many hurts.

Existence itself relies on the positive energy associated with this domain, so a Cleric of any religious tradition might choose it. This domain is associated with agricultural deities, sun gods, gods of healing or endurance, and gods of home and community. Religious orders of healing also seek the powers of this domain.

subclassFeature.name: Disciple of Life
entries: Your healing Spells are empowered by life itself. When a Spell you cast with a Spell Slot restores Hit Points to a creature, that creature regains additional Hit Points on the turn you cast the Spell. The additional Hit Points equal 2 plus the Spell's level.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your connection to this divine domain ensures you always have certain Spells ready. When you reach a Cleric level specified in the Life Domain Spells table, you thereafter always have the listed Spells prepared. These Spells don't count against the number of Spells you can prepare, and they follow the rules of this Class's Spellcasting feature.

subclassFeature.name: Preserve Life
entries: You can use your Channel Divinity to heal a group of the critically injured. As an Action, you expend one use of your Channel Divinity and present your Holy Symbol, restoring a number of Hit Points equal to 5 times your Cleric level.

Choose any creatures within 30 feet of yourself (you can choose yourself), and divide those Hit Points among the chosen creatures. This feature can bring a creature's current Hit Points to no more than half its Hit Point Maximum.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Healer
entries: The healing spells you cast on others heal you as well. When you cast a spell with a Spell Slot on another creature that restores Hit Points to it, you regain Hit Points equal to 2 plus the Spell's level on the turn you cast the Spell.

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Healing
entries: When you would normally roll one or more dice to restore Hit Points to a creature with a Spell that you cast with a Spell Slot, don't roll those dice for the healing; instead use the highest number possible for each die. For example, instead of restoring {@dice 2d6} Hit Points to a creature with a Spell, you restore 12.

race.name: Ardling

items.name: Creature Type:
entries: Humanoid

items.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 4–7 feet tall) or Small (about 3–4 feet tall), chosen when you select this Race

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet

items.name: Life Span:
entries: 200 years on average
As an Ardling adventurer, you have the following special traits.

entries.name: Animal Ancestry
entries: You are descended from a Celestial animal. Choose one of the ancestry types below, then choose one of the example animals listed for that ancestry (or a similar animal); you gain the benefits of that ancestry, and your head resembles the head of the chosen animal:

items.name: Climber (Bear, Cat, Lizard, Squirrel)
entries: You have hooked claws, sharp nails, or a serpentine tail. As a result, you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} equal to your Speed, and once per turn when you deal damage with your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} to a target, you can increase the damage to that target by an amount equal to your Proficiency Bonus.

items.name: Flyer (Bat, Eagle, Owl, Raven)
entries: You have vestigial wings. As a result, when you fall at least 10 feet, you can use your Reaction to safely glide downward, taking no damage from the fall. In addition, when you take the {@action Jump|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, you can flap your wings to gain Advantage on that Action's {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

items.name: Racer (Deer, Dog, Horse, Triceratops)
entries: When you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, your Speed increases for that Action. The increase equals ten times your Proficiency Bonus.

items.name: Swimmer (Crocodile, Dolphin, Frog, Shark)
entries: You can hold your breath for up to an hour at a time, and you have a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} equal to your Speed. In addition, you have Resistance to Cold Damage.

entries.name: Divine Magic
entries: You can innately channel minor divine magic; you know the {@spell Thaumaturgy} Spell. Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, you can replace that Spell with a different 0-level Spell from the Divine Spell list.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for any Spell you cast with this trait (choose the ability when you select the Species).

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have Proficiency in the {@skill Perception} Skill.

items.name: Animal Ancestry
entries: You are descended from a climber Celestial animal, such as a bear, cat, lizard or squirrel. Your head resembles the head of the chosen animal.

You have hooked claws, sharp nails, or a serpentine tail. As a result, you have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} equal to your Speed, and once per turn when you deal damage with your {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} to a target, you can increase the damage to that target by an amount equal to your Proficiency Bonus.

items.name: Animal Ancestry
entries: You are descended from a flyer Celestial animal, such as a bat, eagle, owl or raven. Your head resembles the head of the chosen animal.

You have vestigial wings. As a result, when you fall at least 10 feet, you can use your Reaction to safely glide downward, taking no damage from the fall. In addition, when you take the {@action Jump|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, you can flap your wings to gain Advantage on that Action's {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

items.name: Animal Ancestry
entries: You are descended from a racer Celestial animal, such as a deer, dog, horse or triceratops. Your head resembles the head of the chosen animal.
When you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action, your Speed increases for that Action. The increase equals ten times your Proficiency Bonus.

items.name: Animal Ancestry
entries: You are descended from a swimmer Celestial animal, such as a crocodile, dolphin, frog or shark. Your head resembles the head of the chosen animal.
You can hold your breath for up to an hour at a time, and you have a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} equal to your Speed. In addition, you have Resistance to Cold Damage.

race.name: Dragonborn

items.name: Creature Type:
entries: Humanoid

items.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 5-7 feet tall)

items.name: Speed:
entries: 30 feet

items.name: Life Span:
entries: 80 years on average
As a Dragonborn adventurer, you have the following special traits.

entries.name: Draconic Ancestry
entries: Your lineage stems from a dragon progenitor. Choose the kind of dragon from the Draconic Ancestor table. Your choice affects your Breath Weapon and Damage Resistance traits, as well as the look of your Draconic Flight. The chosen dragon also affects your appearance, with you displaying coloration and other features reminiscent of that dragon.

entries.name: Breath Weapon
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action on your turn, you can replace one of your attacks with an exhalation of magical energy in either a 15-foot cone or a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity Saving Throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 1d10} damage of the type determined by your Draconic Ancestry trait. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage. This damage increases by {@dice 1d10} when you reach the following character levels: 5th level ({@dice 2d10}), 11th level ({@dice 3d10}), and 17th level ({@dice 4d10}).
You can use this Breath Weapon a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have Resistance to the damage type determined by your Draconic Ancestry trait.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision} with a range of 60 feet.

entries.name: Draconic Flight
entries: When you reach 5th level, you learn how to channel the magical energy of your Draconic Ancestry to give yourself temporary flight. As a Bonus Action, you sprout spectral wings on your back that last for 10 minutes or until you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or you retract the wings as a Bonus Action. During that time, you have a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} equal to your Speed. Your wings appear to be made of the energy used by your Breath Weapon. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

items.name: Breath Weapon
entries: As an Action, you exhale destructive energy in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw against a DC equal to 8 + your Constitution modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 1d10} + your character level in {{damage type}} damage. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage.
You can use this Breath Weapon a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

items.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have Resistance to {{damageType}} damage.

race.name: Goliath

items.name: Creature Type:
entries: Humanoid

items.name: Size:
entries: Medium (about 7-8 feet tall)

items.name: Speed:
entries: 35 feet

items.name: Life Span:
entries: 80 years on average
As a Goliath adventurer, you have the following special traits.

entries.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Giants. Choose one of the following benefits—a supernatural boon from your ancestry; you can use the chosen benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}:

items.name: Cloud's Jaunt (Cloud Giant)
entries: As a Bonus Action, you magically Teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

items.name: Fire's Burn (Fire Giant)
entries: When you hit a target with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can also deal {@damage 1d10} Fire Damage to that target .

items.name: Frost's Chill (Frost Giant)
entries: When you hit a target with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can also deal {@damage 1d6} Cold Damage to that target and reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Hill's Tumble (Hill Giant)
entries: When you hit a Large or smaller creature with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can knock that target Prone .

items.name: Stone's Endurance (Stone Giant)
entries: When you take damage, you can use your Reaction to roll a {@dice d12}. Add your Constitution modifier to the number rolled and reduce the damage by that total.

items.name: Storm's Thunder (Storm Giant)
entries: When you take damage from a creature within 60 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to deal {@damage 1d8} Thunder Damage to that creature

entries.name: Large Form
entries: Starting at 5th level, you gain the ability to supernaturally grow. As a Bonus Action, you change your Size to Large, provided you're in a big enough space. This transformation lasts for 10 minutes or until you end it as a Bonus Action. During that duration, you have Advantage on Strength Checks, and your Speed increases by 10 feet. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You have Advantage on any Saving Throw you make to end the {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} condition on yourself. You also count as one Size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Cloud Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
As a Bonus Action, you magically Teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Fire Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
When you hit a target with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can also deal {@damage 1d10} Fire Damage to that target.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Frost Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

When you hit a target with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can also deal {@damage 1d6} Cold Damage to that target and reduce its Speed by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Hill Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
When you hit a Large or smaller creature with an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and deal damage to it, you can knock that target Prone.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Stone Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
When you take damage, you can use your Reaction to roll a {@dice d12}. Add your Constitution modifier to the number rolled and reduce the damage by that total.

items.name: Giant Ancestry
entries: You are descended from Storm Giants. You can use this benefit a number of times equal to your Proficiency Bonus, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
When you take damage from a creature within 60 feet of you, you can use your Reaction to deal {@damage 1d8} Thunder Damage to that creature.

raceFluff.name: Ardling
entries: Celestial animals roam the Beastlands, a plane of untamed beauty and wild nature. Many of those otherworldly animals serve the Beast Lords, and in the early days of the multiverse, some of the animals evolved into bipedal forms. Among their number are Ardlings, people with beastlike heads, keen senses, and an innate connection to divine magic. Long ago, the ancestors of Ardlings migrated to the Material Plane, and Ardlings can now be found on many worlds.

An Ardling has a head resembling that of an animal. Depending on the animal, the Ardling might also have fur, feathers, or scales. Some little and others hulking, Ardlings are as varied as the animals they resemble.

raceFluff.name: Dragonborn
entries: The ancestors of Dragonborn hatched from the eggs of chromatic and metallic dragons. One story holds that these eggs were blessed by the dragon gods Bahamut and Tiamat, who wanted to populate the worlds of the multiverse with people created in their image. Another story holds that dragons created the Dragonborns' progenitors without the gods' blessings. Whatever their origin, Dragonborn have made homes for themselves on the worlds of the Material Plane.

Dragonborn look like wingless, bipedal dragons—scaly, bright-eyed, and thick-boned, with horns on their heads. Dragonborn of chromatic ancestry have scales that are black, blue, green, red, or white, whereas Dragonborn of metallic ancestry have scales that are the color of brass, bronze, copper, gold, or silver.
Like their draconic ancestors, Dragonborn can exhale acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison. One can tell the type of energy a Dragonborn breathes by the color of the Dragonborn's scales.

raceFluff.name: Goliath
entries: Towering over most folk, Goliaths are distant descendants of giants. Each Goliath bears the blessings of the first giants—blessings that manifest in various supernatural boons, including the ability to quickly grow and temporarily approach the height of the Goliaths' gigantic kin.

Goliaths have physical characteristics that are reminiscent of the giants in their family lines. For example, some Goliaths look like stone giants, while others resemble fire giants. Whatever giants they count as kin, Goliaths have forged their own path in the multiverse—unencumbered by the internecine conflicts that have ravaged giant-kind for ages—and seek heights above those reached by their ancestors.

feat.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: You increase one Ability Score of your choice by 2, or you increase two Ability Scores of your choice by 1. You can't increase an Ability Score above 20.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Fate
entries: When another creature that you can see within 60 feet of you makes a {@dice d20} Test, you can roll a {@dice d10} and apply the number rolled as a bonus or a penalty to the {@dice d20} roll. Once you use this benefit, you can't use it again until you roll Initiative or finish a Short Rest or a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Spell Recall
entries: You can cast any spell you have prepared without expending a spell slot, provided the spell is 5th level or lower. Once you do so, you can't use this benefit again until you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

feat.name: Epic Boon of Truesight
entries: You have {@variantrule Truesight|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} out to a range of 60 feet.

spell.name: Aid

components.m: a tiny strip of white cloth

entries: Your spell bolsters creatures, filling them with resolve. Choose up to six creatures within range. Each target gains 5 Temporary Hit Points.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 3rd level or higher, the number of Temporary Hit Points increases by 5 for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Banishment

components.m: an item distasteful to the target

entries: You attempt to send one creature that you can see within range to another plane of existence. The target must succeed on a Charisma Saving Throw or be transported to a harmless demiplane for the duration. The target can willingly fail the save.

While in the demiplane, the target is {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. At the end of each of its turns, the target can repeat the save, ending the Spell on itself on a success. When the Spell ends on the target, it reappears in the space it left or in the nearest unoccupied space if that space is occupied.

If the Spell lasts on the target for 1 minute and the target is an Aberration, a Celestial, an Elemental, a Fey, or a Fiend, the target doesn't return. It is instead transported to a random location on a plane associated with its {@variantrule Creature Type|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this Spell using a Spell Slot of 5th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 4th.

spell.name: Barkskin
entries: You touch one willing creature to protect it with regenerating bark. Until the Spell ends, the target's skin assumes a bark-like appearance, and at the start of each of the target's turns, the target gains a number of Temporary Hit Points equal to your spellcasting ability modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this Spell using a Spell Slot of 3rd level or higher, you can target one additional willing creature for each slot level above 2nd.

spell.name: Guidance

time.condition: which you take in response to you or an ally within 10 feet of you failing an {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}

entries: You channel magical insight to the creature who failed the {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. That creature can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to the check, potentially turning it into a success.

spell.name: Prayer of Healing
entries: You utter an extended prayer of restoration. Choose a number of willing creatures equal to your Spellcasting Ability Modifier (minimum of 1). Each of those creatures who remains within range for the Spell's entire casting gains the benefits of a Short Rest and also regains {@dice 2d8} Hit Points, and a creature can't be affected by this Spell again until that creature finishes a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this Spell using a Spell Slot of 3rd level or higher, the healing increases by {@scaledice 2d8|2-9|1d8} for each slot above 2nd.

spell.name: Resistance

time.condition: which you take in response to you or an ally within 10 feet of you failing a Saving Throw

entries: You channel magical protection to the creature who failed the Saving Throw. That creature can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to the save, potentially turning it into a success.

spell.name: Spiritual Weapon
entries: You create a floating, spectral force that resembles a weapon of your choice and that lasts for the duration. The force appears within range in a space of your choice, and you can immediately make one melee spell attack against a creature within 5 feet of the force. On a hit, the target takes Force Damage equal to {@dice 1d8} + your spellcasting ability modifier.
As a Bonus Action on your later turns, you can move the force up to 20 feet and repeat the attack against a creature within 5 feet of it.

entries.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this Spell using a Spell Slot of 3rd level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 1d8|2-9|1d8} for every slot level above 2nd.

item.name: Priest's Pack
entries: Includes:

entries.name: Light
entries: When you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action on your turn and attack with a Light weapon in one hand and have a Light weapon in the other hand, you can make one extra attack as part of the same Action. That extra attack must be made with the Light weapon in the other hand, and you don't add your ability modifier to the extra attack's damage. You can make this extra attack only once on each of your turns.

For example, if you take the {@action Attack|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action on your turn and have a Shortsword in one hand and a Dagger in the other—each of which has the Light property—you can make one attack with each weapon, but you don't add your Strength or Dexterity modifier to the damage roll of the second weapon.

variantrule.name: Ability Check
entries: The Ability Check is one of three types of {@dice d20} Tests. The rules often call for an Ability Check, and the DM can also call for an Ability Check, determining which ability to use when a creature attempts something (other than an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or a Saving Throw) that has a chance of meaningful failure. When the outcome is uncertain and narratively interesting, the dice determine the results.
The Ability Check has the following special rules.

entries.name: Skills
entries: When you make an Ability Check, the rules or the DM determines whether a Skill Proficiency is relevant to the check. If you have a relevant Skill Proficiency, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to the roll. For example, if a rule refers to a Strength Check ({@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}), you can add your Proficiency Bonus to the check if you have {@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics} Proficiency.

entries.name: Action Required
entries: Making an Ability Check requires you to take an Action unless a rule says otherwise. Several of the named Actions—such as {@action Hide|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and {@action Influence|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}—include Ability Checks. The DM may override this requirement and allow a particular Ability Check to be made as part of a Bonus Action or as no Action at all.

entries.name: Difficulty Class
entries: The DM determines the Difficulty Class of an Ability Check and can override a DC specified in the rules. The Typical Difficulty Class table shows the most common DCs. The default DC for a check is 15, and it is rarely worth calling for an Ability Check if the DC is as low as 5, unless the potential failure is narratively interesting.

variantrule.name: Armor Training
entries: Armor Training is the new name for Armor Proficiency. Any existing rule that involves Armor Proficiency now applies to Armor Training.

If you wear Light, Medium, or Heavy Armor and lack Armor Training with that type of Armor, you have Disadvantage on any {@dice d20} Test you make that involves Strength or Dexterity, and you can't cast Spells.
If you equip a Shield and lack Armor Training with Shields, you don't gain the Armor Class bonus of the Shield.

variantrule.name: Artisan's Tools
entries: Artisan's Tools are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. For a list of Artisan's Tools, see the 2014 Player's Handbook, but ignore the prices there; those tools now cost 15 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Attack Roll
entries: The Attack Roll is one of three types of {@dice d20} Tests. This Unearthed Arcana article uses the rules for attack rolls and critical hits found in the 2014 {@book Player's Handbook|PHB|9|Attack Rolls}.

variantrule.name: Blindsight
entries: If you have Blindsight, you can effectively see within a specific range without relying on physical sight. Within that range, you can effectively see anything that isn't behind Total Cover, even if you're Blinded or in Darkness. Moreover, you can effectively see a {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or an {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} creature in that range.

variantrule.name: Climb Speed
entries: A Climb Speed can be used to move on a vertical surface without expending the extra movement normally associated with climbing. A Climb Speed can also be used in any situation in which your Speed is usable.
Some creatures have the Spider Climb trait, which allows their Climb Speed to work even on the underside of horizontal surfaces.

variantrule.name: Creature Type
entries: All creatures in D&D, including every player character, has a special tag in the rules that identifies the type of creature they are. Most player characters are of the Humanoid type.
Here's a list of the game's Creature Types in alphabetical order:

These types don't have rules themselves, but some rules in the game affect creatures of certain types in different ways. For example, the description of the {@spell Cure Wounds} Spell specifies the healing doesn't work on a Construct.

variantrule.name: D20 Tests
entries: The term {@dice d20} Test encompasses the three main {@dice d20} rolls of the game: Ability Checks, {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls}, and Saving Throws. If something in the game affects {@dice d20} Tests, it affects all three of these rolls.
Whenever a player character rolls a 1 for a {@dice d20} Test, that character gains {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.
The DM determines whether a {@dice d20} Test is warranted in any given circumstance.

variantrule.name: Difficult Terrain
entries: If a space is Difficult Terrain, every foot of movement in that space costs 1 extra foot. For example, moving 5 feet through Difficult Terrain costs 10 feet of movement. Difficult Terrain isn't cumulative; either a space is Difficult Terrain or it isn't.
A space is Difficult Terrain for a creature if the space contains any of the following:

items: Furniture that is Small or larger
Liquid that's between shin- and waist-deep (any deeper and you need to Swim)
Narrow opening that is sized for a creature one
Pit or another gap of 2–5 feet

entries: The DM may determine that other things count as Difficult Terrain based on the examples here.

variantrule.name: Expertise
entries: Expertise is a special feature that enhances your use of a particular Skill Proficiency. If you gain Expertise, you gain it in one Skill in which you have Proficiency. You can never have Expertise in the same Skill Proficiency more than once.

When you make an {@variantrule {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} with a Skill Proficiency in which you have Expertise, your Proficiency Bonus is doubled for that check.

variantrule.name: Fly Speed
entries: A Fly Speed can be used to move through the air. While you have a Fly Speed, you can stay aloft until you land, fall, or die.
While flying, you fall if you are {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or Restrained. If you have the Hover trait, you can stay aloft even while Incapacitated or Restrained.

variantrule.name: Gaming Set
entries: Gaming Sets are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. For a list of Gaming Sets, see the 2014 Player's Handbook, but ignore the prices there; those sets now cost 1 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Heroic Inspiration
entries: When you have Heroic Inspiration (also called Inspiration), you can expend it to give yourself Advantage on a {@dice d20} Test. You decide to do so immediately after rolling the {@dice d20}.

entries.name: Gaining Heroic Inspiration
entries: A player character gains Heroic Inspiration if the character rolls a 1 for a {@dice d20} Test. That 1 must be on the {@dice d20} used for the test's total, not on a {@dice d20} that was rerolled or discarded. This Heroic Inspiration represents a character's resolve to do better after fumbling an attempt.
The DM can also award Heroic Inspiration to a player character who's done something that is particularly heroic or in character.

entries.name: Only One at a Time
entries: You can never have more than one instance of Heroic Inspiration. If something gives you Heroic Inspiration and you already have it, you can give Heroic Inspiration to a player character in your group who lacks it

variantrule.name: Long Rest
entries: A Long Rest is a period of extended downtime—at least 8 hours long—available to any creature. During a Long Rest, you sleep for at least 6 hours and perform no more than 2 hours of light activity, such as reading, talking, eating, or standing watch.

entries.name: Benefits of the Rest
entries: To start a Long Rest, you must have at least 1 Hit Point. When you finish the rest, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Regain All HP
entries: You regain all lost Hit Points.

entries.name: Regain All HD
entries: You regain all spent Hit Dice.

entries.name: HP Max Restored
entries: If your Hit Point Maximum was reduced, it returns to normal.

entries.name: Ability Scores Restored
entries: If any of your Ability Scores were reduced, they return to normal.

entries.name: Exhaustion Reduced
entries: If you are {@condition Exhausted|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, your level of {@condition exhaustion} decreases by 1.
After you finish a Long Rest, you must wait at least 16 hours before starting another one.

entries.name: Interrupting the Rest
entries: A Long Rest is stopped by the following interruptions:

items: Casting a spell other than a 0-level spell • 1 hour of walking or other physical exertion If the rest was at least 1 hour long before the interruption, you gain the benefits of a Short Rest.

entries: You can resume a Long Rest immediately after an interruption. If you do so, the rest requires 1 additional hour to finish per interruption.

variantrule.name: Move
entries: When you Move, you can go a distance equal to your Speed or less. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you can go up to 30 feet when you Move. {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} can slow you down.

entries.name: Breaking Up Your Move
entries: You can break up your Move, using some of its movement before and after any Action you take on the same turn. For example, if you have a Speed of 30 feet, you could go 10 feet, take an Action, and then go 20 feet.

entries.name: Moving Around Other Creatures
entries: During your Move, you can pass through the space of an ally, an {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} creature, a Tiny creature, or a creature who is two Sizes larger or smaller than you.

Another creature's space is {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} for you, unless that creature is Tiny. You can't willingly end your Move in a space occupied by another creature.

entries.name: Climbing and Swimming
entries: You can use your Speed to climb or swim. Some creatures also have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

If you use your Speed to climb or swim, each foot of movement costs 1 extra foot. For example, if you swim or climb 5 feet, you must spend 10 feet of movement to do so with your Speed. If you're swimming or climbing through {@variantrule Difficult Terrain|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, that 5 feet of movement costs 15 feet!

entries.name: Special Speeds
entries: Some creatures have special speeds, such as a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, or a {@variantrule Swim Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. If you have more than one speed, you must choose which one to use each time you take your Move. For example, if you have a Speed and a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, you can use one of those speeds when you Move, not both during the same Move.

If you take more than one Move on a turn and have more than one speed, each Move can use the same speed or a different one. For example, if you have both a Speed and a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} and you take the {@action Dash|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Action on your turn, you could use your Speed for the Move and your {@variantrule Fly Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} for the {@action Dash|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or vice versa.

entries.name: Speed of 0
entries: If an effect zeroes your Speed for a time, any special speed you have is also zeroed for the same duration. For example, if you have a Speed and a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, both speeds are zeroed if you're subjected to the {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Condition.

variantrule.name: Musical Instrument
entries: Musical Instruments are a category of tool with which a character can gain {@variantrule Tool Proficiency|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. For a list of Musical Instruments, see the 2014 Player's Handbook, but ignore the prices there; those instruments now cost 20 GP apiece.

variantrule.name: Ritual Casting
entries: If you have a Spell prepared that has the Ritual tag, you can cast that Spell as a Ritual. A special feature is no longer required for Ritual casting. All the other rules on Rituals in the 2014 Player's Handbook still apply.

variantrule.name: Rules Glossary
entries: This glossary includes game terms that have new or revised meaning in this playtest document, as well as terms, such as {@variantrule Creature Type|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, that aren't defined in the 2014 Player's Handbook. The terms are organized alphabetically.
If a term doesn't appear here, use its definition in the 2014 Player's Handbook, and when playtesting this document, do not use the rules glossary of any other Unearthed {@skill Arcana} article.

entries.name: Arcane Spells
entries: An Arcane Spell draws on the ambient magic of the multiverse. Bards, Sorcerers, Warlocks, and Wizards harness this magic, as do Artificers.
The Arcane Spells table is a partial list of Arcane Spells. The table provides a Spell's level, name, and School of Magic. The list also indicates whether a Spell has the Ritual tag.
If a Spell's School of Magic is different from what appears in the 2014 Player's Handbook, an asterisk (*) appears after the school.

entries.name: Divine Spells
entries: A Divine Spell draws on the power of gods and the Outer Planes. Clerics and Paladins harness this magic.
The Divine Spells table is a partial list of Divine Spells. The table provides a Spell's level, name, and School of Magic. The list also indicates whether a Spell has the Ritual tag.
If a Spell's School of Magic is different from what appears in the 2014 Player's Handbook, an asterisk (*) appears after the school.

entries.name: Primal Spells
entries: A Primal Spell draws on the forces of nature and the Inner Planes. Druids and Rangers harness this magic.
The Primal Spells table is a partial list of Primal Spells. The table provides a Spell's level, name, and School of Magic. The list also indicates whether a Spell has the Ritual tag.
If a Spell's School of Magic is different from what appears in the 2014 Player's Handbook, an asterisk (*) appears after the school.

variantrule.name: Swim Speed
entries: A Swim Speed can be used to move through a liquid without expending the extra movement normally associated with swimming.

variantrule.name: Teleportation
entries: Teleportation is a special kind of magical transportation. If you teleport, you disappear and reappear elsewhere instantly, without moving through the intervening space. This transportation doesn't expend movement, unless a rule tells you otherwise, and teleportation never provokes Opportunity Attacks.

When you teleport, all the equipment you are wearing and carrying teleports with you. If you are touching another creature when you teleport, that creature doesn't teleport with you, unless the teleportation effect says otherwise.
If the destination space of your teleportation is occupied by another creature or blocked by a solid obstacle, you instead appear in the nearest unoccupied space of your choice.
The description of a teleportation effect tells you if you must see the teleportation's destination.

variantrule.name: Tool Proficiency
entries: If you have Proficiency with a tool, you can add your Proficiency Bonus to any {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} you make that uses that tool. If you have Proficiency in the Skill that's also used with that check, you have Advantage on the check too. This means you can benefit from both Skill Proficiency and Tool Proficiency on the same {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}

variantrule.name: Tremorsense
entries: A creature with Tremorsense can pinpoint the location of creatures and moving objects within a specific range, provided that the creature with Tremorsense and anything it's detecting are both in contact with the same surface (such as the ground, a wall, or a ceiling) or the same liquid.
Tremorsense can't detect creatures or objects in the air, and Tremorsense doesn't count as a form of sight.

variantrule.name: Truesight
entries: A creature with Truesight has enhanced vision within a specified range. Within that range, the creature's vision pierces through the following: Darkness. The creature can see in normal and magical darkness.

entries.name: Invisibility
entries: The creature can see {@condition Invisible|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} creatures and objects.

entries.name: Visual Illusions
entries: The creature notices visual illusions and automatically succeeds on Saving Throws against them.

entries.name: Transformations
entries: The creature discerns the true form of any creature or object it sees that has been transformed by magic.

entries.name: Ethereal Plane
entries: The creature can see into the Ethereal Plane

variantrule.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: An Unarmed Strike is a melee attack that involves you using your body to damage, grapple, or shove a target within your Reach.
Your bonus to hit with an Unarmed Strike equals your Strength modifier plus your Proficiency Bonus. On a hit, your Unarmed Strike causes one of the following effects of your choice:

entries.name: Damage
entries: The target takes Bludgeoning Damage equal to 1 + your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Grapple
entries: The target is {@condition Grappled|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, and the grapple's escape DC equals 8 + your Strength modifier + your Proficiency Bonus. This grapple is possible only if the target is no more than one Size larger than you and if you have a hand free to grab the target.

entries.name: Shove
entries: You either push the target 5 feet away or knock the target Prone. This shove is possible only if the target is no more than one Size larger than you.

condition.name: Dazed
entries: While Dazed, you experience the following effect:

items.name: Limited Activity
entries: You can {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or take one Action on your turn, not both. You also can't take a Bonus Action or a Reaction.

condition.name: Exhausted
entries: While Exhausted (known in older books as Exhaustion), you experience the following effects:

items.name: Levels of Exhaustion
items.entry: This Condition is cumulative. Each time you receive it, you gain 1 level of {@condition exhaustion}. You die if your {@condition exhaustion} level exceeds 10.

items.name: d20 Rolls Affected
items.entry: When you make a {@dice d20} Test, you subtract your {@condition exhaustion} level from the {@dice d20} roll.

items.name: Spell Save DCs Affected
items.entry: Subtract your {@condition exhaustion} level from the Spell save DC of any Spell you cast.

items.name: Ending the Condition
items.entry: Finishing a {@variantrule Long Rest|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} removes 1 of your levels of {@condition exhaustion}. When your {@condition exhaustion} level reaches 0, you are no longer Exhausted.

condition.name: Grappled
entries: While you are Grappled, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Speed 0
entries: Your Speed is 0 and can't change.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} against any target other than the grappler.

items.name: Movable
entries: The grappler can drag or carry you when it Moves, but the grappler suffers the {@condition Slowed|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} Condition while moving, unless you are Tiny or two or more Sizes smaller than the grappler.

items.name: Escape
entries: While Grappled, you can make a Dexterity or Strength Saving Throw against the grapple's escape DC at the end of each of your turns, ending the Condition on yourself on a success. The Condition also ends if the grappler is {@condition Incapacitated|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} or if something removes you from the grapple's range.

condition.name: Hidden
entries: While you are Hidden, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Concealed
entries: You aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you are Hidden when you roll Initiative, you have Advantage on the roll.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} against you have Disadvantage, and your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} have Advantage.

items.name: Ending the Condition
entries: The Condition ends on you immediately after any of the following occurrences: you make a sound louder than a whisper, an enemy finds you, you make an Attack Roll, you cast a Spell with a verbal component, or you aren't Heavily Obscured or behind any Cover.

condition.name: Incapacitated
entries: While you are Incapacitated, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Inactive
entries: You can't take Actions or Reactions.

items.name: No Concentration
entries: Your Concentration is broken.

items.name: No Concentration
entries: Your Concentration is broken.

items.name: Speechless
entries: You can't speak.

items.name: Surprised
entries: If you are Incapacitated when you roll Initiative, you have Disadvantage on the roll.

condition.name: Invisible
entries: While you are Invisible, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Unseeable
entries: You can't be seen, so you aren't affected by any effect that requires its target to be seen. Any equipment you are wearing or carrying also can't be seen.

items.name: Surprise
entries: If you are Invisible when you roll initiative, you have Advantage on the roll. Attacks Affected. {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} against you have Disadvantage, and your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} have Advantage.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} against you have Disadvantage, and your {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} have Advantage. If a creature can somehow see you, as with {@variantrule Blindsight|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}, you don't gain this benefit against that creature.

condition.name: Slowed
entries: While you are Slowed, you experience the following effects:

items.name: Limited Movement
entries: You must spend 1 extra foot of movement for every foot you move using your Speed.

items.name: Attacks Affected
entries: {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies|Attack Rolls} against you have Advantage.

items.name: Dexterity Saves Affected
entries: You have Disadvantage on Dexterity Saving Throws.

action.name: Attack
entries: When you take the Attack Action, you can make one attack with a Weapon or an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: Equipping Weapons
entries: You can equip or unequip one Weapon before or after any attack you make as part of this Action, even if the attack is with an {@variantrule Unarmed Strike|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}.

entries.name: Moving Between Attacks
entries: If you {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} on your turn, you can use some or all of that movement to move between the attacks of this Action if you have a feature, such as Extra Attack, that gives you more than one attack as part of the Attack Action.

action.name: Dash
entries: Taking the Dash Action allows you to make a bonus {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} during the current turn.

action.name: Help
entries: When you take the Help Action, you do one of the following:

items.name: Assist Ability Check
entries: Choose one of your Skill Proficiencies and one ally who can see or hear you. You give Advantage to the next {@variantrule Ability Check|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} that ally makes with the chosen Skill. This benefit expires if the ally doesn't use it before the start of your next turn. To give this assistance, you must be near enough to the ally to assist verbally or physically when the ally makes the check. The DM has final say on whether your assistance is possible.

items.name: Assist Attack Roll
entries: You momentarily distract an enemy within 5 feet of you, granting Advantage to the next {@variantrule Attack Roll|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} by one of your allies against that enemy. This benefit expires at the start of your next turn.

action.name: Hide
entries: With the Hide Action, you try to conceal yourself. To do so, you must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity Check ({@skill Stealth}) while you're Heavily Obscured or behind Three-Quarters Cover or Total Cover, and you must be out of any visible enemy's line of sight; if you can see a creature, you can discern whether it can see you.

On a successful check, you are {@condition Hidden|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies}. Make note of your check's total, which becomes the DC for a creature to find you with a Wisdom Check ({@skill Perception}).

action.name: Influence
entries: With the Influence Action, you can try to influence another creature to do something you request or demand. This Action can be used only on creatures controlled by the DM, and it isn't mind control; it can't force a creature to do something that is counter to the creature's alignment or that is otherwise repugnant to the creature.
This Action has three main parts: Attitude, interaction, and a Charisma Check.

entries.name: Attitude
entries: A creature's Attitude determines how a character can influence that creature. Each DM controlled creature has one of the following Attitudes toward the player characters:

items.name: Indifferent
entries: This is the default Attitude for DMcontrolled creatures. An Indifferent creature might help or hinder the party, depending on what the creature sees as most beneficial. A creature's indifference doesn't necessarily make it standoffish or disinterested. Indifferent creatures might be polite and genial, surly and irritable, or anything in between. A successful Charisma Check is often necessary when the adventurers try to persuade an Indifferent creature to do something.

items.name: Friendly
entries: A Friendly creature wants to help the adventurers and wishes for them to succeed. For tasks or actions that require no particular risk, effort, or cost, Friendly creatures often help happily. If an element of personal risk is involved, a successful Charisma Check might be required to convince a Friendly creature to take that risk.

items.name: Hostile
entries: A Hostile creature opposes the adventurers and their goals but doesn't necessarily attack them on sight. The adventurers need to succeed on one or more challenging Charisma Checks to convince a Hostile creature to do anything on the party's behalf; however, the DM might determine that the Hostile creature is so ill-disposed toward the characters that no Charisma Check can sway it, in which case the first check fails automatically and no further Influence attempts can be made on the creature unless its Attitude shifts.

entries.name: Interaction
entries: When you take the Influence Action, either roleplay how your character interacts with the creature or describe your character's behavior—focusing on your character's request or demand. If the interaction is especially suited to the creature's desires and outlook, the DM might grant Advantage to your subsequent check or might temporarily shift a Hostile creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Friendly.

Similarly, if the interaction is particularly irksome to the creature, the DM might impose Disadvantage on your subsequent check or might temporarily shift a Friendly creature to Indifferent or an Indifferent creature to Hostile.

entries.name: Ability Check
entries: To determine whether your request or demand is successful, you make a Charisma Check. You have Advantage on the check if the creature is Friendly, and you have Disadvantage if the creature is Hostile.

entries.name: Choosing a Skill
entries: The Influence Skills table suggests which Skills are applicable when you make the Charisma Check, depending on the interaction that precedes the roll.

entries.caption: Influence Skills
rows: Gently coaxing a Beast or a Monstrosity
Deceiving a creature that can understand you
Persuading a creature that can understand you

entries.name: Setting the DC
entries: The minimum DC for the check is 15 or the creature's Intelligence score, whichever is higher. Outcome. If your check succeeds, the creature does as asked. If your check fails, you must wait to make the same request again. The default wait time is 24 hours, which the DM may shorten or extend depending on the circumstances.

action.name: Jump
entries: With the Jump Action, you attempt to leap more than 5 feet (a jump of 5 feet or less is treated as Difficult Terrain). When you take this Action, your Speed must be greater than 0, and you must make a {@dc 10} Strength Check ({@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Athletics}). If you don't {@variantrule Move|XUA2022ClericAndRevisedSpecies} at least 10 feet immediately before this Action, you have Disadvantage on the check.
On a failed check, you leap 5 feet horizontally or vertically.

On a successful check, the check's total determines the distance in feet that you can clear horizontally, or half that total if you're jumping vertically (round down). This jump doesn't expend your movement, but the distance you clear can't exceed your Speed.

action.name: Magic
entries: When you take the Magic Action, you cast a Spell that has a casting time of an Action, or you use a Magic Item that requires an Action to be activated.

If you cast a Spell that has a casting time of 1 minute or longer, you must take the Magic Action on each turn of that casting, and you must maintain Concentration while you do so. If your Concentration is broken, the Spell fails, but you don't expend a Spell Slot.

action.name: Search
entries: When you take the Search Action, you make a Wisdom Check to discern something that isn't obvious. The Search table suggests which Skills are applicable when you take this Action, depending on what you're trying to detect.

action.name: Study
entries: When you take the Study Action, you make an Intelligence Check to study your memory, a book, a creature, a clue, an object, or another source of knowledge and call to mind an important piece of information about it.
The Areas of Knowledge table suggests which Skills are applicable when you take this Action, depending on the area of knowledge the Intelligence Check is about.

entries.caption: Areas of Knowledge
rows: Spells, magic items, eldritch symbols, magical traditions, planes of existence, and certain creatures (Aberrations, Constructs, Elementals, Fey, and Monstrosities)
Historic events and people, ancient civilizations, wars, and certain creatures (Giants and Humanoids)
Terrain, flora, weather, and certain creatures (Beasts, Dragons, Oozes, and Plants)
Deities, religious hierarchies and rites, holy symbols, cults, and certain creatures (Celestials, Fiends, and Undead)
